articles.headline: Fears Growing as Syrians Wait for U.S. Attack
articles.snippet: Many Syrians are bracing for the worst, some with a deep sense of fatalism, and the expectation of imminent strikes has halted normal life.
articles.abstract: Many Syrians are bracing for the worst, some with a deep sense of fatalism, and the expectation of imminent strikes has halted normal life.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In a narrow alley in the old city of Damascus, a shopkeeper who opposes the Syrian government spent Thursday as usual, drinking coffee with the other merchants who keep him company in place of long-vanished tourists. But the calm on the cobblestone street, he said, could hardly mask the fear and ambivalence over an American military strike.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Shutdown at Nasdaq Is Traced to Software
articles.snippet: The Nasdaq OMX Group attributed last week’s three-hour trading halt a surge of data that overwhelmed its server, in the stock market operator’s most detailed accounting yet of the market outage.
articles.abstract: The Nasdaq OMX Group attributed last week’s three-hour trading halt a surge of data that overwhelmed its server, in the stock market operator’s most detailed accounting yet of the market outage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Though the Nasdaq market calls itself home for the stocks of the world’s biggest technology companies, the exchange acknowledged on Thursday that a three-hour halt in trading arose from a problem with its software.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Obama Set for Limited Strike on Syria as British Vote No
articles.snippet: President Obama is ready to pursue a limited military strike even with a rejection of such action by Britain and mounting questions from Congress, officials said.
articles.abstract: President Obama is ready to pursue a limited military strike even with a rejection of such action by Britain and mounting questions from Congress, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is prepared to move ahead with a limited military strike on Syria, administration officials said Thursday, despite a stinging rejection of such action by America’s stalwart ally Britain and mounting questions from Congress.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Not Crying for Argentina but Fearful of a Ruling
articles.snippet: The U. S. and the International Monetary Fund are concerned about a decision that would force Argentina to pay all its creditors equally and hold processing banks responsible if the country did not.
articles.abstract: The U. S. and the International Monetary Fund are concerned about a decision that would force Argentina to pay all its creditors equally and hold processing banks responsible if the country did not.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the world of sovereign debt defaults, it is hard to imagine a less sympathetic debtor than Argentina. It has defaulted again and again for nearly two centuries, with few apologies. After the country’s most recent default, in 2001, it refused to negotiate for four years and then offered creditors a deal worth about 30 cents on the dollar — and vowed that those who refused would receive nothing.

articles.headline: New Neighbor’s Agenda: White Power Takeover
articles.snippet: Residents of Leith, N.D., thought nothing of it when Paul Craig Cobb moved in and began buying property, until they learned of his plan to start a white supremacist colony.
articles.abstract: Residents of Leith, N.D., thought nothing of it when Paul Craig Cobb moved in and began buying property, until they learned of his plan to start a white supremacist colony.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEITH, N.D. — The bearded man with thinning, gray-and-bleach-blond hair flapping down his neck first appeared in this tiny agricultural town last year, quietly and inconspicuously roaming the crackly dirt roads.

articles.headline: Taylor Farms, Big Food Supplier, Grapples With Frequent Recalls
articles.snippet: Taylor Farms, a giant supplier of produce and other food products, has a recent record of recalls that industry experts call high.
articles.abstract: Taylor Farms, a giant supplier of produce and other food products, has a recent record of recalls that industry experts call high.
articles.lead_paragraph: Taylor Farms, the large vegetable producer whose salad mix is being investigated in connection with an outbreak of illness involving hundreds of people in 22 states, has had an unusual number of voluntary recalls for potentially tainted products in the last three years.

articles.headline: E-Cigarette Makers’ Ads Echo Tobacco’s Heyday
articles.snippet: Antismoking advocates criticize e-cigarette manufacturers for using the same marketing methods as big tobacco did in the 1950s and ’60s.
articles.abstract: Antismoking advocates criticize e-cigarette manufacturers for using the same marketing methods as big tobacco did in the 1950s and ’60s.
articles.lead_paragraph: Electronic cigarettes may be a creation of the early 21st century, but critics of the devices say manufacturers are increasingly borrowing marketing tactics that are more reminiscent of the heady days of tobacco in the mid-1900s.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Hiring Put China’s Elite on an Easy Track
articles.snippet: A hiring program intended to weed out nepotism in the bank’s China operations instead has led to a federal bribery investigation in the United States, interviews and a government document show.
articles.abstract: A hiring program intended to weed out nepotism in the bank’s China operations instead has led to a federal bribery investigation in the United States, interviews and a government document show.
articles.lead_paragraph: The program was originally called “Sons and Daughters.” And although it was supposed to protect JPMorgan Chase’s business dealings in China, the program went so off track that it is now the focus of a federal bribery investigation in the United States, interviews and a confidential government document show.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: A Top Banker’s Image, Clouded
articles.snippet: Zurich Insurance said it would look into whether its chief financial officer was under undue pressure before he killed himself, leading to the resignation of Josef Ackermann as chairman.
articles.abstract: Zurich Insurance said it would look into whether its chief financial officer was under undue pressure before he killed himself, leading to the resignation of Josef Ackermann as chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — During a long career that took him to the top of the European banking world, the Swiss executive Josef Ackermann has survived countless boardroom intrigues and even a criminal prosecution.
